message.content:
To determine which sheet will have greater friction, we need to consider the characteristics of the two surfaces. Friction is the force that resists motion when two surfaces are in contact with each other. 

In this case, the sandpaper has a rough surface with tiny abrasive particles, which provides more resistance to motion when compared to the smooth surface of the plain paper. The rougher surface of the sandpaper creates more contact points with the finger, leading to a greater amount of friction. 

Thus, the correct answer is (B) the sandpaper, as it will have greater friction than the plain paper. Option (A) is incorrect because the plain paper has a smooth surface, which results in less friction. Option (C) is incorrect because both surfaces have friction due to the resistance to motion. Option (D) is also incorrect because the sandpaper and plain paper have different levels of friction.

This question requires an understanding of the concept of friction. Friction is the resistance to motion between two objects in contact with each other. Sandpaper has a rough surface due to the grains of sand embedded in it, which increases the contact points between the paper and the object running across it. This increased contact points result in a greater amount of friction compared to a smooth surface like plain paper. Therefore, the sandpaper will have greater friction than the plain paper. Option (A) is incorrect because the rough surface of the sandpaper creates more friction. Option (C) is incorrect because both surfaces have friction. Option (D) is incorrect because the sandpaper has greater friction.

Friction is the force that opposes the motion of two surfaces sliding against each other. In this scenario, when running your finger across a sheet of plain paper, there will be some friction present. However, when running your finger across a sheet of sandpaper, the friction will be greater. This is because sandpaper has a rough and abrasive surface, which increases the resistance and makes it harder for your finger to slide smoothly. Option (A) is incorrect because the plain paper will have less friction compared to the sandpaper. Option (C) is incorrect because both the plain paper and sandpaper will have friction. Option (D) is incorrect because the sandpaper will have greater friction than the plain paper.

This question requires knowledge about the factors that determine the amount of friction between two surfaces. Sandpaper is specifically designed to increase friction, so it will have greater friction compared to plain paper. Option (A) is incorrect because plain paper has a smoother surface, leading to less friction. Option (C) is incorrect because friction is present between any two surfaces in contact. Option (D) is incorrect because the two surfaces have different textures, resulting in different frictional forces.

This question requires understanding of the concept of friction. Friction is the force that resists the relative motion between two surfaces in contact. Sandpaper has a rough surface with tiny abrasive particles, which creates more resistance and increases the friction when compared to plain paper. Therefore, the answer is option (B) - the sandpaper. Option (A) is incorrect because plain paper has a smooth surface that offers less resistance. Option (C) is incorrect because both surfaces do have friction. Option (D) is also incorrect because the sandpaper has greater friction than the plain paper.

This question requires knowledge of friction and the properties of different surfaces. Friction is the force that resists motion between two objects in contact, and it depends on the roughness of the surfaces. Sandpaper has a rough surface with tiny abrasive particles that create more resistance, resulting in greater friction when compared to plain paper. Therefore, option (B) - the sand paper - will have greater friction. Option (A) is incorrect because plain paper has a smoother surface with less resistance. Option (C) is incorrect because both paper and sandpaper have friction. Option (D) is incorrect because the friction between the two surfaces is not the same.

This question requires some understanding of the concept of friction. Friction is the force that opposes the motion of two surfaces sliding against each other. In this case, when you run your finger across a sheet of sandpaper, the rough texture of the sandpaper creates more contact points with your finger, resulting in greater friction compared to running your finger across a smooth sheet of plain paper. Therefore, option (B) is the correct answer. Option (A) is incorrect because the smooth surface of the plain paper will have less friction. Option (C) is incorrect because both surfaces will have friction. Option (D) is incorrect because the sandpaper will have greater friction than the plain paper.

This question requires some basic knowledge about friction. Friction is the force that resists motion when two surfaces come into contact with each other. Sandpaper has a rough texture compared to plain paper, which means it has more surface area in contact with your finger. More surface area in contact means there will be more friction. Therefore, the sandpaper will have greater friction compared to the plain paper. Option (A) is incorrect because the plain paper has a smoother surface and less surface area in contact with your finger, resulting in less friction. Option (C) is incorrect because both surfaces will have friction. Option (D) is incorrect because the sandpaper will have greater friction due to its rough texture.

Friction is the force that occurs when two objects rub against each other. Sandpaper has a rough texture due to the abrasive particles on its surface, while plain paper has a smoother surface. The rough texture of sandpaper creates more points of contact with the surface being rubbed and therefore increases the friction. Therefore, the sheet of sandpaper will have greater friction than the plain paper. Option (A) is incorrect because the smooth texture of plain paper reduces friction. Option (C) is incorrect because both materials will have friction. Option (D) is incorrect because the sandpaper will have greater friction.

This question requires understanding of how friction works. Friction is the resistance to motion between two surfaces that are in contact with each other. Sandpaper has a rough texture due to the small abrasive particles on its surface, which increases the friction between the paper and your finger when it is dragged across. On the other hand, plain paper has a smoother surface, so there is less friction when your finger is run across it. Therefore, the sheet of sandpaper will have greater friction. Option (A) and (C) are incorrect because friction is present in this scenario. Option (D) is incorrect because the friction is different between the two surfaces.

This question requires some basic knowledge about friction and the factors that affect it. Friction is the force that acts between two surfaces in contact with each other and opposes their relative motion. The amount of friction depends on several factors, including the roughness of the surfaces. In this case, sandpaper is known for its rough texture, while plain paper is generally smooth. Rough surfaces create more friction because they have more contact points. Therefore, when you run your finger across a sheet of sandpaper and a sheet of plain paper, the sandpaper will have greater friction. Options (A) and (C) are incorrect because friction exists between surfaces in contact, and option (D) is incorrect because the two surfaces have different roughnesses, leading to different amounts of friction.

This question requires some basic knowledge about friction. Friction is a force that opposes motion when two surfaces come into contact with each other. Sand paper is specifically designed to have a rough surface, which increases the amount of friction between the paper and any object that touches it. In comparison, plain paper has a smooth surface, which results in less friction. Therefore, sand paper will have greater friction than plain paper. Option (A) is incorrect because plain paper has less friction. Option (C) is untrue because both paper and sand paper experience friction. Option (D) is also incorrect because the friction is not the same for both surfaces.

Sand paper has a rough surface, which increases the likelihood of interlocking with other surfaces and therefore increases the friction between them.
